chapters.title: The Diagnosis and the Door
chapters.summary: Leo, a terminally ill archivist, receives his final prognosis and retreats to his private archive, where a surge of despair accidentally opens a stable portal for the first time.
key_events: Leo is given weeks to live by his doctor.
He returns to his cluttered, personal archive of oddities.
Overwhelmed by emotion, he unintentionally focuses his latent power on a strange, inherited compass.
A shimmering portal tears open in the air of his study.
A small, terrified goblin clutching a tattered book tumbles through before the portal collapses.
chapters.ending_hook: Leo stares at the shivering creature, who looks up and says, 'You… you’re a Key. They’ll be coming for you now.'

chapters.title: The First Exile
chapters.summary: Leo learns about his 'guest,' the poet-goblin Poggle, and gets his first glimpse of the corporation hunting him when agents arrive at his door.
key_events: Poggle explains he is a 'Verse-Exile,' cast out of his world for the crime of 'unprofitable poetry.'
He reveals Leo is a 'World-Key,' a genetic anomaly able to open portals without technology.
Black-suited agents of the OmniCorp conglomerate arrive, scanning for dimensional energy.
Leo and Poggle hide in a sub-basement as the agents search his archive.
Poggle mentions the 'Stacks of Avalon' as a myth where all exiles dream of finding refuge.
chapters.ending_hook: Watching the agents leave, Leo sees one drop a metallic tracker. They haven't given up; they're laying a trap.

chapters.title: A Warrior's Debt
chapters.summary: Under pressure, Leo opens another portal, summoning the disgraced warrior Bryn, who mistakes Leo for her captor and attacks.
key_events: Leo, panicked about the tracker, tries to open a portal to send Poggle home but lacks control.
The portal instead pulls in Bryn, a hulting warrior from a bronze-age world, mid-battle.
A brief, chaotic fight ensues in the archive.
Bryn calms upon realizing Leo is not OmniCorp; she was exiled for refusing to slaughter innocents.
She pledges a life-debt to Leo for pulling her from her doomed last stand, adding her strength to his cause.
chapters.ending_hook: As Bryn swears her oath, the melancholic *tick-tock* of a clockwork owl emerges from the still-flickering portal, but the owl itself does not appear.

chapters.title: The Clockwork Heart
chapters.summary: The group tracks the sound to a forgotten storage unit, finding the sentient owl, Cogsworth, whose heart is a failing dimensional stabilizer.
key_events: Following the ticking, they find a storage unit belonging to Leo's mysterious grandfather.
Inside is Cogsworth, a majestic but dusty clockwork owl, who speaks in weary, poetic riddles.
Cogsworth reveals he was built by Leo's grandfather, the last known World-Key, as a guide and stabilizer.
His core mechanism is failing; without repair, Leo's portals will become unstable and lethal.
Cogsworth confirms the Stacks of Avalon are real—and its Central Index could save them all.
chapters.ending_hook: Cogsworth projects a holographic map pointing to the first 'Page' or anchor point to Avalon, located not in another world, but deep within the flooded subway tunnels beneath the city.

chapters.title: Tunnels of the Drowned Echo
chapters.summary: The group ventures into the submerged ruins to find the first anchor, pursued by OmniCorp's aquatic hunters.
key_events: The team navigates the dark, flooded tunnels.
They encounter the 'Drowned Echo,' a ghostly collective memory of the city that tries to trap them in nostalgia.
Bryn fights off spectral guardians while Poggle decipheres water-worn runes on the walls.
Leo uses his growing power to calm the Echo, earning its trust.
They find the anchor: a stone plinth holding a single, indestructible page of crystal.
chapters.ending_hook: As Leo touches the page, it lights up, but so does the OmniCorp tracker. Their location is revealed, and sleek, predatory submersibles rise from the dark water around them.

chapters.title: Capture and Consequence
chapters.summary: OmniCorp captures the group, taking them to a sterile extraction facility where Leo learns the horrific truth of their plans.
key_events: The team is overwhelmed and captured by OmniCorp's tech.
They are taken to a white, sterile facility on a remote island.
The Director explains they harvest World-Key genetics to mass-produce portal weapons for dimensional strip-mining.
Leo is strapped to a machine to begin the extraction process, which is fatal.
Bryn's guilt is weaponized; she's shown visions of the world she failed to save.
chapters.ending_hook: As the machine powers up, Cogsworth, whom they dismissed as a broken tool, winks one brass eye—his ticking shifts to a deliberate, urgent pattern. A sabotage protocol activates.

chapters.title: The Broken Cage
chapters.summary: Cogsworth's sacrifice allows a chaotic escape, but the team is scattered across different sectors of the facility, each facing their own trial.
key_events: Cogsworth overloads his core, causing a massive power failure and breaching containment cells holding other exotic creatures.
Leo, freed, must navigate the chaotic facility.
Bryn fights her way through security drones, reclaiming her weapon.
Poggle uses his knowledge of bureaucracy to hack the door systems.
They reunite at a hangar, but Cogsworth is now inert, his core dark.
chapters.ending_hook: In the hangar, they don't find a ship, but a single, unstable OmniCorp prototype portal generator—and the only world listed in its memory is Bryn's doomed homeland.

chapters.title: The Ashes of Home
chapters.summary: Using the prototype, they escape to Bryn's world, a ravaged landscape where she must confront the consequences of her exile.
key_events: They arrive to find Bryn's world a post-apocalyptic wasteland, stripped by OmniCorp.
Bryn finds the survivors she thought she'd failed, who reveal they hid because of her last stand.
The survivors view her not as a failure, but as the inspiration that made them resilient.
Leo's illness flares badly in the toxic atmosphere.
The local shaman offers a temporary remedy, but says only the 'Root of Realities' in the Stacks of Avalon can cure a World-Key's ailment.
chapters.ending_hook: As Bryn makes peace, OmniCorp tracking signals pierce the sky. They were followed. The Director's voice booms from a drone: 'You only borrowed the Key, Archivist. We are here to repossess.'

chapters.title: The Poet's Gambit
chapters.summary: Cornered in the ruins, Poggle devises a plan that uses his 'unprofitable' poetry not as a weapon, but as a key to a different kind of power.
key_events: The group is pinned down in a canyon by OmniCorp forces.
Poggle realizes the canyon's rock formations are naturally resonant, like a giant tuning fork.
He insists on reciting his epic poem, the very one he was exiled for.
The poem, combined with the resonance and a surge from Leo, doesn't attack OmniCorp, but opens dozens of micro-portals to peaceful, vibrant worlds.
The beauty and chaos cause the corporate soldiers to hesitate and malfunction, creating a diversion.
chapters.ending_hook: The diversion works, but the effort drains Leo completely. As he collapses, the second crystal Page in his pack resonates, *pulling* them all through a spontaneous portal into a void of swirling, living books.

chapters.title: The Endless Stacks
chapters.summary: The team arrives in the Stacks of Avalon—a labyrinthine, living library at the heart of reality—and must pass its ultimate test: the Cataloguer.
key_events: They find themselves in the impossible, infinite Stacks.
Cogsworth, in this place of pure knowledge, stirs back to life, his purpose fulfilled.
They are judged by the Cataloguer, a being of pure information that tests their worthiness.
Leo argues their worth is not in purity or power, but in their found family and shared scars.
The Cataloguer accepts this, revealing the Central Index—and the Root of Realities, a glowing tree of light.
chapters.ending_hook: As Leo reaches for the Root, the fabric of the Stacks tears. The Director and an OmniCorp army have forced their way in, using a weaponized Key derived from Leo's stolen genetics. 'This library,' the Director declares, 'is now a subsidiary.'

chapters.title: A Family of Exiles
chapters.summary: In the heart of the library, the team makes their final stand, not with sheer force, but by using the unique traits that made them exiles.
key_events: A massive battle erupts among the living bookshelves.
Bryn leads the physical defense, coordinating with other exiled beings drawn to the conflict.
Poggle and Cogsworth work to hack/convince the library's own defenses to reject OmniCorp's invasive presence.
Leo realizes the Director's power is a crude copy; his own, born of mortality and meaning, is more nuanced.
He proposes not to destroy the invader, but to *re-catalog* them, using the library's own power.
chapters.ending_hook: Leo opens a portal not to banish, but to envelop the Director, offering the Stacks' infinite stories. The Director, overwhelmed by the beauty and chaos of raw, uncommodified existence, is absorbed. But the effort leaves Leo dying, the Root just out of reach.

chapters.title: The Last Page
chapters.summary: With the threat neutralized, Leo must choose between his cure and the future of his newfound family and the Stacks.
key_events: Leo is fading, the Root's light nearby.
His friends urge him to take it, but he sees the Stacks are damaged, the exiles homeless.
He makes a choice: he uses the last of his Key power not to heal himself, but to permanently anchor the Stacks as a sanctuary for all exiles, securing its doors.
As the power leaves him, the Stacks themselves respond. The Root sheds a single, glowing leaf that falls upon his chest.
It doesn't cure his illness, but transforms it; he will live, bound to the library as its permanent, mortal Librarian.
chapters.ending_hook: Leo stands on a balcony overlooking the infinite Stacks, now bustling with exiled beings finding solace. Bryn trains new guardians, Poggle writes in a grand studio, and Cogsworth perches on his shoulder, ticking contentedly. Leo smiles, not just a Key or a patient, but a part of a story much bigger than himself. The title of his first catalog entry appears in the air: *Family, Found (Cross-Dimensional).*
